channel.title: 经济学人
channel.description: 这是一个追踪经济学人news的种子

item.title: 弗拉基米尔-普京几乎不需要干涉美国民主。国内政客们乐于在自己的⬇️。
item.description:
Vladimir Putin hardly needs to interfere in American democracy. Domestic politicians are happy to spread dysfunction on their own https://t.co/raoPRHnvMl ⬇️

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 为什么 Nvidia 的芯片在人工智能市场占据主导地位？该公司有三大优势： 👇
item.description:
Why do Nvidia’s chips dominate the AI market? The firm has three big advantages: https://t.co/cnBTLox0Dr 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 通过数字分组来解释历史正在流行。列表式文章承诺，历史是可以分解和理解的，五件（或一百件）事情就是你需要知道的全部👇。
item.description:
Explaining history through numerical groupings is in vogue. Listicles promise that history can be broken down and understood, and that five (or 100) things is all you need to know https://t.co/rrX7E6xQF2 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 纯粹主义者可能会认为《道林-格雷的画像》是舞台艺术对名人和噱头的屈服。他们错了：
item.description:
Purists might see “The Picture of Dorian Gray” as stage­ craft’s capitulation to celebrity and gim­micks. They would be wrong: https://t.co/gU5DYMmN1c pic.twitter.com/zeVdSRdkr6

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 世事变迁 👇
item.description:
Things have changed https://t.co/GAyT3UTjd2 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 乌克兰人希望，在阿夫杰夫卡沦陷后，俄罗斯人会暂停休整。但他们并不走运。浏览我们的卫星跟踪器，看看战争在哪里白热化： 👇
item.description:
Ukrainians hoped that after the fall of Avdiivka, the Russians would pause to recuperate. But they have had no such luck. Explore our satellite tracker to see where the war has heated up: https://t.co/7097CRqnL1 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 姜黄正在杀人。发展中国家--尤其是印度--应该学习孟加拉国公开、务实的尝试，防止这种情况发生👇。
item.description:
Turmeric is killing people. Developing countries—especially India—should learn from Bangladesh’s open, pragmatic attempts to prevent this from happening https://t.co/towzn2mdy3 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 刘易斯-汉密尔顿（Lewis Hamilton）从梅赛德斯车队转投法拉利车队可谓有史以来最大的转会。它将为一级方程式新赛季增添一出精彩的杂耍🏎️。
item.description:
Lewis Hamilton’s move from Mercedes to Ferrari is arguably the biggest transfer of all time. It will add a splended sideshow to the new Formula One season https://t.co/KUOjOW7rXl 🏎️

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 英国穆斯林对工党的支持正在动摇。但在下次大选中，这种支持率下降的后果将是有限的，原因有两个 👇
item.description:
British Muslims’ support for Labour is wobbling. But the consequences of this decline in support at the next general election would be limited for two reasons https://t.co/BqJERIXXtJ 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 自 1990 年以来，成年人的肥胖率翻了一番，儿童和青少年的肥胖率则翻了两番。我们的地图显示了哪些国家的肥胖率最高：
item.description:
Obesity rates have doubled among adults since 1990 and quadrupled among children and adolescents. Our map shows which countries have the highest rates: https://t.co/KQN7XzCJzW pic.twitter.com/DUvmSFajBR

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 西方车展正走向没落。中国企业在维持它们的生命👇。
item.description:
Car shows in the West are in terminal decline. Chinese firms are keeping them on life support https://t.co/iKpG2mJ5nm 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 囤积氧化铀--经过加工和浓缩后是核弹和反应堆的主要燃料--似乎是一种更适合超级恶棍而非投资者的策略。但投机者现在有多种方式参与其中 👇
item.description:
Hoarding uranium oxide—which, once processed and enriched, is the main fuel for nuclear bombs and reactors—might seem like a strategy more suitable for supervillains than investors.

But speculators now have a number of ways to get involved https://t.co/KxlEpntIMn 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: "@纳坦-沙兰斯基写道："我在狱中的时光与纳瓦尔尼在狱中的时光有一个很大的不同。"在我那个时代，西方政客......将苏联政治犯的命运视为他们自身安全的一部分。现在他们不这么认为了"。
item.description:
“There was one big difference between my time in prison and Navalny’s,” writes @NatanSharansky.

“In my time Western politicians...saw the fate of Soviet political prisoners as part of their own security. Now they don’t” https://t.co/8rOCGFxOiw

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 没有新的策略就无法战胜芬太尼。如果无法阻止毒品流入消费者手中，就必须采取更多措施帮助他们应对毒品 👇。
item.description:
Fentanyl cannot be defeated without new tactics. If it is impossible to stop the drug getting to consumers, more must be done to help them cope with it https://t.co/Zh3A1n9F7o 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 密歇根州民主党初选的结果如果在 11 月重演，唐纳德-特朗普将成为总统 ⬇️
item.description:
The result in Michigan’s Democratic primary would make Donald Trump president if it’s repeated in November https://t.co/sgFzpZWpA8 ⬇️

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 工会很少向企业掠夺者寻求灵感。但激进投资不再是对冲基金鲨鱼的专利。埃克森美孚和星巴克是最新趋势的受害者👇。
item.description:
Trade unions rarely look to corporate raiders for inspiration. But activist investing is no longer the preserve of hedge-fund sharks. ExxonMobil and Starbucks are victims of the latest trend https://t.co/MFFhML4PoI 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 纽约市面临的问题有多棘手？我们的 "制衡 "播客进行了调查。敬请收听 @JohnPrideaux、@chowardchoward 和 @imkahloon 👇 。
item.description:
How intractable are the problems facing New York City? Our “Checks and Balance” podcast investigates. With @JohnPrideaux, @chowardchoward and @imkahloon https://t.co/iCV7zOlsaD 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 自 1843 年 9 月起，《经济学家》开始出版，以参与 "勇往直前的智慧与不值一提的怯懦无知之间的激烈较量"。现在，您可以通过我们的历史游戏👇 测试自己的知识水平。
item.description:
Since September 1843 The Economist has been published to take part in “a severe contest between intelligence, which presses forward, and an unworthy, timid ignorance”.

Now you can test your own knowledge with our history game https://t.co/lODP0s3e3O 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 为大多数电动汽车提供动力的电池是其最昂贵的部件，通常占新车价格的 40%左右。随着电动汽车销售的放缓，汽车制造商希望通过更便宜、更强大的电池来提高销量。
item.description:
The batteries that power most EVs are their single most-expensive component, typically representing some 40% of the price of a new vehicle. As sales of EVs slow, carmakers are hoping to rev up sales with both cheaper and more-powerful batteries https://t.co/WVQh8rtU1H 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 对于巧克力迷来说，可可价格在一月份创下了历史新高。这给巧克力行业和嗜甜的消费者都带来了麻烦👇。
item.description:
Bitter news for chocolate fans: cocoa prices reached an all-time high in January. That spells trouble for the industry and sweet-toothed consumers alike https://t.co/NuuGW0Hx2k 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 2022 年弗拉基米尔-普京入侵乌克兰后，七国集团冻结了俄罗斯的外汇储备资产，并禁止金融公司转移这些资产。
item.description:
After Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine in 2022, the G7 froze Russia’s foreign reserve assets and prohibited financial firms from moving them.

Western policymakers are now considering whether they can be used to help Ukraine https://t.co/Gi6Xl1kj26 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 法国的断头台处决一直持续到 20 世纪 70 年代末。关于 "情报"：向终结了 "情报 "的罗伯特-巴丹泰致敬
item.description:
Execution by guillotine continued in France all the way until the late 1970s. On “The Intelligence”: a tribute to Robert Badinter, who brought about an end to it https://t.co/WiWdnlgFYJ pic.twitter.com/DmHdioV3jg

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 印度人民党控制着印度的中央政府以及较贫穷、人口较多的北部地区的许多邦。但该党在较富裕、受教育程度较高的南部地区却举步维艰。该党能否扭转局面？ 👇
item.description:
The BJP controls India’s central government and many of the states in the poorer, more populous north. But it has struggled to make inroads in the richer, better-educated south. Can the party turn things around? https://t.co/RHrT8kSlZU 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 大规模的农民抗议活动令印度总理头疼不已。即使最近的抗议得到了控制，但不满情绪依然存在 👇
item.description:
Massive farmers’ protests are a headache for India’s prime minister. Even if the recent ones have been contained, discontent remains https://t.co/HGF69rpHxq 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 伊朗毛拉曾经努力提高选民投票率。现在，他们对自己的不受欢迎已经心灰意冷，几乎懒得去管了。乏善可陈的竞选活动说明了什么？ 👇
item.description:
Iran’s mullahs once strove to increase voter turnout. Now they are so resigned to their unpopularity that they hardly bother. What does the lacklustre election campaign say about the state of the regime? https://t.co/Vzh3kjqyA3 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 经过十年可怕的攀升，美国每年因芬太尼过量致死的人数似乎终于放缓了攀升的速度。在打击美国历史上最致命的毒品的斗争中，这就是成功的标志👇。
item.description:
After a decade of horrifying ascent, the yearly number of fatal fentanyl overdoses in America appears at last to be slowing to a gentle climb. In the fight against the deadliest narcotic in the country’s history, that is what passes for success https://t.co/bmwNOnzUqg 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 美国在所谓的禁毒战争中长期努力寻找可靠的盟友，这其中有两个问题 👇
item.description:
Two problems underlie the long struggle the United States has had in finding reliable allies in the so-called war on drugs https://t.co/kMoIgzsRop 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 西方的历史与你在学校学到的不太一样。文明的概念相对较新--一本新书揭露了它的愚蠢👇。
item.description:
The history of the West is not quite what you learned in school. The idea of civilisation is relatively recent—a new book exposes its folly https://t.co/5ncm8a4Uej 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 在所谓的禁毒战争中，美国长期以来一直在努力寻找可靠的盟友。阅读原因： 👇
item.description:
The United States has long struggled to find reliable allies in the so-called war on drugs. Read why: https://t.co/2xKfznqQv4 👇

— The Economist (@TheEconomist) March 1, 2024

item.title: 是时候投资马尔贝克了吗？阿根廷企业主如何评估哈维尔-米莱 👇

Is it time to invest in a spot of Malbec? How Argentine business-owners size up Javier Milei https://t.co/xe47d6yJpo 👇
